mn105:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
mn105:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

mn105:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulehi bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā hoti:
mn105:2.1.eng: Now at that time several mendicants had declared their enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence:
mn105:2.1.comm: Also at SN 12.70:4.1, which concerns the dubious ordination of the wanderer Susīma. | “Enlightenment” is aññā, a technical term that refers to the knowledge of perfection (arahattā). | A Buddhist mendicant incurs a penalty of expulsion if they deliberately lay false claim to awakening (Bu Pj 4), and a penalty of confession if they truthfully claim awakening to someone who is not ordained (Bu Pc 8). These rules directly concern laying claim regarding oneself, but the background stories apply when making claims with regards to another. Mendicants may declare their attainments among the community of monks and nuns who are fully ordained. Typically such a solemn matter is spoken of in a formal and respectful manner with one’s teacher.

mn105:2.2.pli: “‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmā”ti.
mn105:2.2.eng: “We understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

mn105:2.3.eng: Sunakkhatta the Licchavi heard about this.
mn105:2.3.comm: This is apparently Sunakkhatta’s first meeting with the Buddha. In DN 6:5.3 we learn that, after being ordained three years, he spoke of his limited success in meditation. MN 12 and DN 24 deal with his bitter criticisms of the Buddha shortly after his disrobal.

mn105:2.4.pli: “sambahulehi kira bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā hoti:

mn105:2.5.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’”ti.

mn105:3.1.pli: Atha kho sunakkhatto licchaviputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sunakkhatto licchaviputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn105:3.1.eng: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

mn105:4.2.pli: ‘sambahulehi kira bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā—
mn105:4.2.eng: several mendicants have declared their enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence.

mn105:4.3.pli: khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’ti.

mn105:4.4.pli: Ye te, bhante, bhikkhū bhagavato santike aññaṃ byākaṃsu:

mn105:4.5.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’ti, kacci te, bhante, bhikkhū sammadeva aññaṃ byākaṃsu udāhu santetthekacce bhikkhū adhimānena aññaṃ byākaṃsū”ti?
mn105:4.5.eng: I trust they did so rightly—or are there some who declared enlightenment out of overestimation?”
mn105:4.5.comm: By a loophole in the wording of the Vinaya, it is not an offence to tell anyone of your attainments if you are genuinely deluded and falsely believe that you have an attainment that you do not have. The Buddha dismissed such “overestimation” (adhimāna) as “negligible” (Bu Pj 4:2.1).

mn105:5.1.pli: “Ye te, sunakkhatta, bhikkhū mama santike aññaṃ byākaṃsu:

mn105:5.2.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’ti.

mn105:5.3.pli: Santetthekacce bhikkhū sammadeva aññaṃ byākaṃsu, santi panidhekacce bhikkhū adhimānenapi aññaṃ byākaṃsu.
mn105:5.3.eng: “Some of them did so rightly, Sunakkhatta, while others did so out of overestimation.

mn105:5.4.pli: Tatra, sunakkhatta, ye te bhikkhū sammadeva aññaṃ byākaṃsu tesaṃ taṃ tatheva hoti;
mn105:5.4.eng: Now, when mendicants declare enlightenment rightly, that is their truth.

mn105:5.5.pli: ye pana te bhikkhū adhimānena aññaṃ byākaṃsu tatra, sunakkhatta, tathāgatassa evaṃ hoti:
mn105:5.5.eng: But when mendicants declare enlightenment out of overestimation, the Realized One thinks:

mn105:5.8.eng: he should teach them the Dhamma,

mn105:5.9.pli: Atha ca panidhekacce moghapurisā pañhaṃ abhisaṅkharitvā abhisaṅkharitvā tathāgataṃ upasaṅkamitvā pucchanti.
mn105:5.9.eng: but then certain futile men, having carefully planned a question, approach the Realized One and ask it,

mn105:5.10.pli: Tatra, sunakkhatta, yampi tathāgatassa evaṃ hoti:

mn105:5.11.comm: That is, if they plan to trap the Buddha with sophistry, he realizes that they are not ready to be taught.

mn105:6.1.eng: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

mn105:6.2.pli: yaṃ bhagavā dhammaṃ deseyya. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
mn105:6.2.eng: Let the Buddha teach the Dhamma. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

mn105:6.3.pli: “Tena hi, sunakkhatta, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn105:6.3.eng: “Well then, Sunakkhatta, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn105:6.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho sunakkhatto licchaviputto bhagavato paccassosi.

mn105:7.1.eng: “Sunakkhatta, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn105:7.3.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
mn105:7.3.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn105:7.7.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā—
mn105:7.7.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn105:7.8.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn105:8.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco purisapuggalo lokāmisādhimutto assa.
mn105:8.1.eng: It’s possible that a certain individual person may be intent on worldly pleasures of the flesh.

mn105:8.2.pli: Lokāmisādhimuttassa kho, sunakkhatta, purisapuggalassa tappatirūpī ceva kathā saṇṭhāti, tadanudhammañca anuvitakketi, anuvicāreti, tañca purisaṃ bhajati, tena ca vittiṃ āpajjati;
mn105:8.2.eng: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it rewarding.

mn105:8.3.pli: āneñjapaṭisaṃyuttāya ca pana kathāya kacchamānāya na sussūsati, na sotaṃ odahati, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti, na ca taṃ purisaṃ bhajati, na ca tena vittiṃ āpajjati.
mn105:8.3.eng: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it rewarding.
mn105:8.3.comm: The “imperturbable” refers to high meditative attainments, typically the fourth absorption and above.

mn105:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, puriso sakamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā ciravippavuttho assa.
mn105:9.1.eng: Suppose a person had left their own village or town long ago,

mn105:9.2.pli: So aññataraṃ purisaṃ passeyya tamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā acirapakkantaṃ.
mn105:9.2.eng: and they saw another person who had only recently left there.

mn105:9.3.pli: So taṃ purisaṃ tassa gāmassa vā nigamassa vā khematañca subhikkhatañca appābādhatañca puccheyya;
mn105:9.3.eng: They would ask about whether their village was safe, with plenty of food and little disease,

mn105:9.4.pli: tassa so puriso tassa gāmassa vā nigamassa vā khematañca subhikkhatañca appābādhatañca saṃseyya.
mn105:9.4.eng: and the other person would tell them the news.

mn105:9.6.pli: api nu so puriso tassa purisassa sussūseyya, sotaṃ odaheyya, aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhāpeyya, tañca purisaṃ bhajeyya, tena ca vittiṃ āpajjeyyā”ti?
mn105:9.6.eng: Would that person want to listen to that other person? Would they actively listen and try to understand? Would they associate with that person, and find it rewarding?”

mn105:9.8.pli: “Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati yaṃ idhekacco purisapuggalo lokāmisādhimutto assa.
mn105:9.8.eng: “In the same way, it’s possible that a certain individual may be intent on worldly pleasures of the flesh.

mn105:9.9.pli: Lokāmisādhimuttassa kho, sunakkhatta, purisapuggalassa tappatirūpī ceva kathā saṇṭhāti, tadanudhammañca anuvitakketi, anuvicāreti, tañca purisaṃ bhajati, tena ca vittiṃ āpajjati;
mn105:9.9.eng: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it rewarding.

mn105:9.10.pli: āneñjapaṭisaṃyuttāya ca pana kathāya kacchamānāya na sussūsati, na sotaṃ odahati, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti, na ca taṃ purisaṃ bhajati, na ca tena vittiṃ āpajjati.
mn105:9.10.eng: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it rewarding.

mn105:9.12.eng: ‘That individual is intent on pleasures of the flesh, for they’re detached from things connected with the imperturbable.’
mn105:9.12.comm: The reading āneñjasaṁyojanena hi kho visaṁyutto is problematic, as it suggests they are free of the fetter of the imperturbable, which would mean they are an arahant. Several manuscripts omit this phrase, but it is glossed in the commentary. I think it harks back to the immediately prior āneñjapaṭisaṁyuttāya; possibly the paṭi dropped out in an old misreading. They’re not detached from the “fetter” of the imperturbable, but from “what is connected with” the imperturbable, i.e. they are disinterested in the talk about it.

mn105:10.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco purisapuggalo āneñjādhimutto assa.
mn105:10.1.eng: It’s possible that a certain individual person may be intent on the imperturbable.

mn105:10.2.pli: Āneñjādhimuttassa kho, sunakkhatta, purisapuggalassa tappatirūpī ceva kathā saṇṭhāti, tadanudhammañca anuvitakketi, anuvicāreti, tañca purisaṃ bhajati, tena ca vittiṃ āpajjati;
mn105:10.2.eng: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it rewarding.

mn105:10.3.pli: lokāmisapaṭisaṃyuttāya ca pana kathāya kacchamānāya na sussūsati, na sotaṃ odahati, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti, na ca taṃ purisaṃ bhajati, na ca tena vittiṃ āpajjati.
mn105:10.3.eng: But when talk connected with worldly pleasures of the flesh is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it rewarding.

mn105:11.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, paṇḍupalāso bandhanā pavutto abhabbo haritattāya;
mn105:11.1.eng: Suppose there was a fallen, withered leaf. It’s incapable of becoming green again.

mn105:11.2.pli: evameva kho, sunakkhatta, āneñjādhimuttassa purisapuggalassa ye lokāmisasaṃyojane se pavutte.
mn105:11.2.eng: In the same way, an individual intent on the imperturbable has dropped the connection with worldly pleasures of the flesh.
mn105:11.2.comm: Here and in the following examples, the verb in the explanation follows the metaphor: a leaf is “dropped”, a stone is “broken”, etc.

mn105:11.4.eng: ‘That individual is intent on the imperturbable, for they’re detached from things connected with pleasures of the flesh.’

mn105:12.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco purisapuggalo ākiñcaññāyatanādhimutto assa.
mn105:12.1.eng: It’s possible that a certain individual person may be intent on the dimension of nothingness.

mn105:12.2.pli: Ākiñcaññāyatanādhimuttassa kho, sunakkhatta, purisapuggalassa tappatirūpī ceva kathā saṇṭhāti, tadanudhammañca anuvitakketi, anuvicāreti, tañca purisaṃ bhajati, tena ca vittiṃ āpajjati;
mn105:12.2.eng: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it rewarding.
mn105:12.2.comm: This case and the next would apply to the Buddha’s former teachers, who taught the dimensions of nothingness and neither perception nor non-perception respectively (MN 26:15.1).

mn105:12.3.pli: āneñjapaṭisaṃyuttāya ca pana kathāya kacchamānāya na sussūsati, na sotaṃ odahati, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti, na ca taṃ purisaṃ bhajati, na ca tena vittiṃ āpajjati.
mn105:12.3.eng: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it rewarding.
mn105:12.3.comm: In this case, the “imperturbable” must refer to the fourth absorption and the first two formless attainments.

mn105:13.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, puthusilā dvedhābhinnā appaṭisandhikā hoti;
mn105:13.1.eng: Suppose there was a broad rock that had been broken in half, so that it could not be put back together again.

mn105:13.2.pli: evameva kho, sunakkhatta, ākiñcaññāyatanādhimuttassa purisapuggalassa ye āneñjasaṃyojane se bhinne.
mn105:13.2.eng: In the same way, an individual intent on the dimension of nothingness has broken the connection with the imperturbable.

mn105:13.4.eng: ‘That individual is intent on the dimension of nothingness, for they’re detached from things connected with the imperturbable.’

mn105:14.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco purisapuggalo nevasaññānāsaññāyatanādhimutto assa.
mn105:14.1.eng: It’s possible that a certain individual person may be intent on the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

mn105:14.2.pli: Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanādhimuttassa kho, sunakkhatta, purisapuggalassa tappatirūpī ceva kathā saṇṭhāti, tadanudhammañca anuvitakketi, anuvicāreti, tañca purisaṃ bhajati, tena ca vittiṃ āpajjati;
mn105:14.2.eng: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it rewarding.

mn105:14.3.pli: ākiñcaññāyatanapaṭisaṃyuttāya ca pana kathāya kacchamānāya na sussūsati, na sotaṃ odahati, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti, na ca taṃ purisaṃ bhajati, na ca tena vittiṃ āpajjati.
mn105:14.3.eng: But when talk connected with the dimension of nothingness is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it rewarding.

mn105:15.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, puriso manuññabhojanaṃ bhuttāvī chaḍḍeyya.
mn105:15.1.eng: Suppose someone had eaten some satisfying food and thrown it up.

mn105:15.3.pli: api nu tassa purisassa tasmiṃ bhatte puna bhottukamyatā assā”ti?
mn105:15.3.eng: Would that person want to eat that food again?”

mn105:15.6.eng: Because that food is deemed repulsive.”

mn105:15.7.pli: “Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanādhimuttassa purisapuggalassa ye ākiñcaññāyatanasaṃyojane se vante.
mn105:15.7.eng: “In the same way, an individual intent on the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception has vomited the connection with the dimension of nothingness.

mn105:15.9.eng: ‘That individual is intent on the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, for they’re detached from things connected with the dimension of nothingness.’

mn105:16.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco purisapuggalo sammā nibbānādhimutto assa.
mn105:16.1.eng: It’s possible that a certain individual person may be rightly intent on extinguishment.

mn105:16.2.pli: Sammā nibbānādhimuttassa kho, sunakkhatta, purisapuggalassa tappatirūpī ceva kathā saṇṭhāti, tadanudhammañca anuvitakketi, anuvicāreti, tañca purisaṃ bhajati, tena ca vittiṃ āpajjati;
mn105:16.2.eng: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it rewarding.

mn105:16.3.pli: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanapaṭisaṃyuttāya ca pana kathāya kacchamānāya na sussūsati, na sotaṃ odahati, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti, na ca taṃ purisaṃ bhajati, na ca tena vittiṃ āpajjati.
mn105:16.3.eng: But when talk connected with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it rewarding.

mn105:17.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, tālo matthakacchinno abhabbo puna viruḷhiyā;
mn105:17.1.eng: Suppose there was a palm tree with its crown cut off. It’s incapable of further growth.

mn105:17.2.pli: evameva kho, sunakkhatta, sammā nibbānādhimuttassa purisapuggalassa ye nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaṃyojane se ucchinnamūle tālāvatthukate anabhāvaṅkate āyatiṃ anuppādadhamme.
mn105:17.2.eng: In the same way, an individual rightly intent on extinguishment has cut off the connection with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

mn105:17.4.pli: ‘nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaṃyojanena hi kho visaṃyutto sammā nibbānādhimutto purisapuggalo’ti.
mn105:17.4.eng: ‘That individual is rightly intent on extinguishment, for they’re detached from things connected with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

mn105:18.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṃ idhekaccassa bhikkhuno evamassa:
mn105:18.1.eng: It’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:
mn105:18.1.comm: The Buddha goes on to discuss a case of overestimation.

mn105:18.2.pli: ‘taṇhā kho sallaṃ samaṇena vuttaṃ, avijjāvisadoso, chandarāgabyāpādena ruppati.
mn105:18.2.eng: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.
mn105:18.2.comm: Here, the “Ascetic” (samaṇa) is the Buddha.

mn105:18.3.pli: Taṃ me taṇhāsallaṃ pahīnaṃ, apanīto avijjāvisadoso, sammā nibbānādhimuttohamasmī’ti.
mn105:18.3.eng: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’

mn105:18.4.eng: Having such conceit, though it’s not based in fact,

mn105:18.5.pli: So yāni sammā nibbānādhimuttassa asappāyāni tāni anuyuñjeyya; asappāyaṃ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṃ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ sotena saddaṃ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ ghānena gandhaṃ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ jivhāya rasaṃ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ manasā dhammaṃ anuyuñjeyya.
mn105:18.5.eng: they would engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

mn105:18.6.pli: Tassa asappāyaṃ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṃ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ sotena saddaṃ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ ghānena gandhaṃ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ jivhāya rasaṃ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ manasā dhammaṃ anuyuttassa rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseyya.
mn105:18.6.eng: Doing so, lust infects their mind,

mn105:18.7.pli: So rāgānuddhaṃsitena cittena maraṇaṃ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
mn105:18.7.eng: resulting in death or deadly pain.

mn105:19.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, puriso sallena viddho assa savisena gāḷhūpalepanena.
mn105:19.1.eng: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.

mn105:19.2.pli: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṃ sallakattaṃ upaṭṭhāpeyyuṃ.
mn105:19.2.eng: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.

mn105:19.3.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto satthena vaṇamukhaṃ parikanteyya.
mn105:19.3.eng: The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel,

mn105:19.4.pli: Satthena vaṇamukhaṃ parikantitvā esaniyā sallaṃ eseyya.

mn105:19.5.pli: Esaniyā sallaṃ esitvā sallaṃ abbuheyya, apaneyya visadosaṃ saupādisesaṃ.
mn105:19.5.eng: extract it, and expel the poison, leaving some residue behind.
mn105:19.5.comm: The term saupādisesa is better known as a description of those who have attained Nibbana “with residue”, namely the five aggregates that persist so long as life lasts. The prefix upādi is usually taken as derived from upādāna, normally “grasping”, but here in its secondary sense of “material cause, fuel”. The “residue” of poison is the material cause of potential harm, just as the five aggregates still entail a residue of physical suffering for a perfected one.

mn105:19.6.eng: Imagining that no residue remained, the surgeon would say:
mn105:19.6.comm: For “imagining that no residue remained”, I follow PTS and Siamese editions, which have anupādiseso ti maññamāno. Bodhi’s note 1003 to his Middle Length Discourses points out that earlier manuscripts support this reading, which seems to have been “corrected” to saupādisesoti jānamāno in the Burmese Sixth Council edition on which SuttaCentral’s Mahāsaṅgīti edition is based. A Sanskrit fragment also supports the PTS/Siamese reading: (sā)va(ś)eṣaṁ nira(vaśe)ṣaṁ (iti manyamānaḥ) (SHT IV 500 folio 3V3, cited in Analayo, Comparative Study, p. 611, note 136).

mn105:19.7.pli: ‘ambho purisa, ubbhataṃ kho te sallaṃ, apanīto visadoso saupādiseso.
mn105:19.7.eng: ‘My good man, the dart has been extracted and the poison expelled without residue.

mn105:19.8.eng: It is still capable of harming you.
mn105:19.8.comm: Most editions have “not capable” of harming here, which seems odd given that the doctor immediately goes on to describe how to mitigate possible harm. I follow the PTS edition, which is alone in reading alañ ca te antarāyāya. This is supported by a Sanskrit fragment, which reads ala(ṁ)te-t(r)-ānta(rā)yāya (SHT IV 500 folio 3V4, cited in Analayo, ibid.).

mn105:19.9.pli: Sappāyāni ceva bhojanāni bhuñjeyyāsi, mā te asappāyāni bhojanāni bhuñjato vaṇo assāvī assa.
mn105:19.9.eng: Eat only suitable food. Don’t eat unsuitable food, or else the wound may get infected.

mn105:19.10.pli: Kālena kālañca vaṇaṃ dhoveyyāsi, kālena kālaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ ālimpeyyāsi, mā te na kālena kālaṃ vaṇaṃ dhovato na kālena kālaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ ālimpato pubbalohitaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ pariyonandhi.
mn105:19.10.eng: Regularly wash the wound and anoint the opening, or else it’ll get covered with pus and blood.

mn105:19.11.pli: Mā ca vātātape cārittaṃ anuyuñji, mā te vātātape cārittaṃ anuyuttassa rajosūkaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ anuddhaṃsesi.
mn105:19.11.eng: Don’t walk too much in the wind and sun, or else dust and dirt will infect the wound.

mn105:19.12.pli: Vaṇānurakkhī ca, ambho purisa, vihareyyāsi vaṇasāropī’ti.
mn105:19.12.eng: Take care of the wound, my good fellow, heal it.’

mn105:20.2.pli: ‘ubbhataṃ kho me sallaṃ, apanīto visadoso anupādiseso.
mn105:20.2.eng: ‘The dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.

mn105:20.3.eng: It’s not capable of harming me.’
mn105:20.3.comm: Pali editions all agree that the patient thinks it cannot cause harm, which, if we adopt the PTS reading as I have above, implies that the patient misunderstood the doctor’s instructions. A Sanskrit fragment says that he did understand that it could cause harm, suggesting that he did what was unsuitable despite knowing this: niravaśeṣaḥ a(panīto) viṣa-doṣaḥ alaṁ (me-tr)-ān(ta)rā(yāya) (SHT IV 500 folio 3R3, cited in Analayo, ibid.). I don’t follow this as it is not found in any Pali edition.

mn105:20.4.pli: So asappāyāni ceva bhojanāni bhuñjeyya. Tassa asappāyāni bhojanāni bhuñjato vaṇo assāvī assa.
mn105:20.4.eng: They’d eat unsuitable food, and the wound would get infected.

mn105:20.5.pli: Na ca kālena kālaṃ vaṇaṃ dhoveyya, na ca kālena kālaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ ālimpeyya. Tassa na kālena kālaṃ vaṇaṃ dhovato, na kālena kālaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ ālimpato pubbalohitaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ pariyonandheyya.
mn105:20.5.eng: And they wouldn’t regularly wash and anoint the opening, so it would get covered in pus and blood.

mn105:20.6.pli: Vātātape ca cārittaṃ anuyuñjeyya. Tassa vātātape cārittaṃ anuyuttassa rajosūkaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ anuddhaṃseyya.
mn105:20.6.eng: And they’d walk too much in the wind and sun, so dust and dirt infected the wound.

mn105:20.7.pli: Na ca vaṇānurakkhī vihareyya na vaṇasāropī.
mn105:20.7.eng: And they wouldn’t take care of the wound or heal it.

mn105:20.8.pli: Tassa imissā ca asappāyakiriyāya, asuci visadoso apanīto saupādiseso tadubhayena vaṇo puthuttaṃ gaccheyya.
mn105:20.8.eng: Then both because they did what was unsuitable, and because of the residue of unclean poison, the wound would expand,

mn105:20.9.pli: So puthuttaṃ gatena vaṇena maraṇaṃ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
mn105:20.9.eng: resulting in death or deadly pain.

mn105:21.1.pli: Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati yaṃ idhekaccassa bhikkhuno evamassa:
mn105:21.1.eng: In the same way, it’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:

mn105:21.2.pli: ‘taṇhā kho sallaṃ samaṇena vuttaṃ, avijjāvisadoso chandarāgabyāpādena ruppati.
mn105:21.2.eng: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.

mn105:21.3.pli: Taṃ me taṇhāsallaṃ pahīnaṃ, apanīto avijjāvisadoso, sammā nibbānādhimuttohamasmī’ti.
mn105:21.3.eng: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’

mn105:21.4.eng: Having such conceit, though it’s not based in fact,

mn105:21.5.pli: So yāni sammā nibbānādhimuttassa asappāyāni tāni anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṃ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ sotena saddaṃ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ ghānena gandhaṃ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ jivhāya rasaṃ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ manasā dhammaṃ anuyuñjeyya.
mn105:21.5.eng: they would engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

mn105:21.6.pli: Tassa asappāyaṃ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṃ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ sotena saddaṃ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ ghānena gandhaṃ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ jivhāya rasaṃ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ manasā dhammaṃ anuyuttassa rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseyya.
mn105:21.6.eng: Doing so, lust infects their mind,

mn105:21.7.pli: So rāgānuddhaṃsitena cittena maraṇaṃ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
mn105:21.7.eng: resulting in death or deadly pain.

mn105:22.1.pli: Maraṇañhetaṃ, sunakkhatta, ariyassa vinaye yo sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati;
mn105:22.1.eng: For it is death in the training of the Noble One to disavow the training and return to a lesser life.

mn105:22.2.pli: maraṇamattañhetaṃ, sunakkhatta, dukkhaṃ yaṃ aññataraṃ saṅkiliṭṭhaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjati.
mn105:22.2.eng: And it is deadly pain to commit one of the corrupt offenses.

mn105:23.1.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṃ idhekaccassa bhikkhuno evamassa:
mn105:23.1.eng: It’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:

mn105:23.2.pli: ‘taṇhā kho sallaṃ samaṇena vuttaṃ, avijjāvisadoso chandarāgabyāpādena ruppati.
mn105:23.2.eng: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.

mn105:23.3.pli: Taṃ me taṇhāsallaṃ pahīnaṃ, apanīto avijjāvisadoso, sammā nibbānādhimuttohamasmī’ti.
mn105:23.3.eng: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’

mn105:23.4.pli: Sammā nibbānādhimuttasseva sato so yāni sammā nibbānādhimuttassa asappāyāni tāni nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṃ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ sotena saddaṃ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ ghānena gandhaṃ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ jivhāya rasaṃ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ manasā dhammaṃ nānuyuñjeyya.
mn105:23.4.eng: Being rightly intent on extinguishment, they wouldn’t engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

mn105:23.5.pli: Tassa asappāyaṃ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṃ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ sotena saddaṃ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ ghānena gandhaṃ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ jivhāya rasaṃ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ manasā dhammaṃ nānuyuttassa rāgo cittaṃ nānuddhaṃseyya.
mn105:23.5.eng: Doing so, lust wouldn’t infect their mind,

mn105:23.6.pli: So na rāgānuddhaṃsitena cittena neva maraṇaṃ vā nigaccheyya na maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
mn105:23.6.eng: so no death or deadly pain would result.

mn105:24.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, puriso sallena viddho assa savisena gāḷhūpalepanena.
mn105:24.1.eng: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.

mn105:24.2.pli: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṃ sallakattaṃ upaṭṭhāpeyyuṃ.
mn105:24.2.eng: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.

mn105:24.3.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto satthena vaṇamukhaṃ parikanteyya.
mn105:24.3.eng: The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel,

mn105:24.4.pli: Satthena vaṇamukhaṃ parikantitvā esaniyā sallaṃ eseyya.

mn105:24.5.pli: Esaniyā sallaṃ esitvā sallaṃ abbuheyya, apaneyya visadosaṃ anupādisesaṃ.
mn105:24.5.eng: extract it, and expel the poison, leaving no residue behind.

mn105:24.6.eng: Knowing that no residue remained, the surgeon would say:

mn105:24.7.pli: ‘ambho purisa, ubbhataṃ kho te sallaṃ, apanīto visadoso anupādiseso.
mn105:24.7.eng: ‘My good man, the dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.

mn105:24.8.eng: It’s not capable of harming you.

mn105:24.9.pli: Sappāyāni ceva bhojanāni bhuñjeyyāsi, mā te asappāyāni bhojanāni bhuñjato vaṇo assāvī assa.
mn105:24.9.eng: Eat only suitable food. Don’t eat unsuitable food, or else the wound may get infected.

mn105:24.10.pli: Kālena kālañca vaṇaṃ dhoveyyāsi, kālena kālaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ ālimpeyyāsi. Mā te na kālena kālaṃ vaṇaṃ dhovato na kālena kālaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ ālimpato pubbalohitaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ pariyonandhi.
mn105:24.10.eng: Regularly wash the wound and anoint the opening, or else it’ll get covered with pus and blood.

mn105:24.11.pli: Mā ca vātātape cārittaṃ anuyuñji, mā te vātātape cārittaṃ anuyuttassa rajosūkaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ anuddhaṃsesi.
mn105:24.11.eng: Don’t walk too much in the wind and sun, or else dust and dirt will infect the wound.

mn105:24.12.pli: Vaṇānurakkhī ca, ambho purisa, vihareyyāsi vaṇasāropī’ti.
mn105:24.12.eng: Take care of the wound, my good fellow, heal it.’

mn105:25.2.pli: ‘ubbhataṃ kho me sallaṃ, apanīto visadoso anupādiseso.
mn105:25.2.eng: ‘The dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.

mn105:25.3.eng: It’s not capable of harming me.’

mn105:25.4.pli: So sappāyāni ceva bhojanāni bhuñjeyya. Tassa sappāyāni bhojanāni bhuñjato vaṇo na assāvī assa.
mn105:25.4.eng: They’d eat suitable food, and the wound wouldn’t get infected.

mn105:25.5.pli: Kālena kālañca vaṇaṃ dhoveyya, kālena kālaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ ālimpeyya. Tassa kālena kālaṃ vaṇaṃ dhovato kālena kālaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ ālimpato na pubbalohitaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ pariyonandheyya.
mn105:25.5.eng: And they’d regularly wash and anoint the opening, so it wouldn’t get covered in pus and blood.

mn105:25.6.pli: Na ca vātātape cārittaṃ anuyuñjeyya. Tassa vātātape cārittaṃ ananuyuttassa rajosūkaṃ vaṇamukhaṃ nānuddhaṃseyya.
mn105:25.6.eng: And they wouldn’t walk too much in the wind and sun, so dust and dirt wouldn’t infect the wound.

mn105:25.7.eng: And they’d take care of the wound and heal it.

mn105:25.8.pli: Tassa imissā ca sappāyakiriyāya asu ca visadoso apanīto anupādiseso tadubhayena vaṇo viruheyya.
mn105:25.8.eng: Then both because they did what was suitable, and the unclean poison had left no residue, the wound would heal,

mn105:25.9.pli: So ruḷhena vaṇena sañchavinā neva maraṇaṃ vā nigaccheyya na maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
mn105:25.9.eng: and no death or deadly pain would result.

mn105:26.1.pli: Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati yaṃ idhekaccassa bhikkhuno evamassa:
mn105:26.1.eng: In the same way, it’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:

mn105:26.2.pli: ‘taṇhā kho sallaṃ samaṇena vuttaṃ, avijjāvisadoso chandarāgabyāpādena ruppati.
mn105:26.2.eng: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.

mn105:26.3.pli: Taṃ me taṇhāsallaṃ pahīnaṃ, apanīto avijjāvisadoso, sammā nibbānādhimuttohamasmī’ti.
mn105:26.3.eng: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’

mn105:26.4.pli: Sammā nibbānādhimuttasseva sato so yāni sammā nibbānādhimuttassa asappāyāni tāni nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṃ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ sotena saddaṃ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ ghānena gandhaṃ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ jivhāya rasaṃ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṃ manasā dhammaṃ nānuyuñjeyya.
mn105:26.4.eng: Being rightly intent on extinguishment, they wouldn’t engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

mn105:26.5.pli: Tassa asappāyaṃ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṃ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ sotena saddaṃ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ ghānena gandhaṃ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ jivhāya rasaṃ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṃ manasā dhammaṃ nānuyuttassa, rāgo cittaṃ nānuddhaṃseyya.
mn105:26.5.eng: Doing so, lust wouldn’t infect their mind,

mn105:26.6.pli: So na rāgānuddhaṃsitena cittena neva maraṇaṃ vā nigaccheyya na maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
mn105:26.6.eng: so no death or deadly pain would result.

mn105:27.1.pli: Upamā kho me ayaṃ, sunakkhatta, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
mn105:27.1.eng: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.

mn105:27.3.pli: vaṇoti kho, sunakkhatta, channetaṃ ajjhattikānaṃ āyatanānaṃ adhivacanaṃ;
mn105:27.3.eng: ‘Wound’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.

mn105:27.7.pli: satthanti kho, sunakkhatta, ariyāyetaṃ paññāya adhivacanaṃ;
mn105:27.7.eng: ‘Scalpel’ is a term for noble wisdom.

mn105:27.8.pli: bhisakko sallakattoti kho, sunakkhatta, tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
mn105:27.8.eng: ‘Surgeon’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

mn105:28.1.pli: So vata, sunakkhatta, bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu saṃvutakārī.
mn105:28.1.eng: Truly, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.

mn105:28.2.pli: ‘Upadhi dukkhassa mūlan’ti—iti viditvā nirupadhi upadhisaṅkhaye vimutto upadhismiṃ vā kāyaṃ upasaṃharissati cittaṃ vā uppādessatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mn105:28.2.eng: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.
mn105:28.2.comm: “Attachment” here is upadhi, which is both the things of the world to which we cling, and the inner clinging. The Jains defined upadhi similarly (Tattvārthasūtra 9.26). The dominant meaning in Sanskrit is “fraud”, which perhaps informs the Buddhist sense.

mn105:29.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, āpānīyakaṃso vaṇṇasampanno gandhasampanno rasasampanno;
mn105:29.1.eng: Suppose there was a bronze goblet of beverage that had a nice color, aroma, and flavor.

mn105:29.2.eng: But it was mixed with poison.

mn105:29.3.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhapaṭikūlo.
mn105:29.3.eng: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.

mn105:29.5.pli: api nu so puriso amuṃ āpānīyakaṃsaṃ piveyya yaṃ jaññā:
mn105:29.5.eng: Would that person drink that beverage if they knew that

mn105:29.6.pli: ‘imāhaṃ pivitvā maraṇaṃ vā nigacchāmi maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhan’”ti?
mn105:29.6.eng: it would result in death or deadly suffering?”

mn105:29.8.pli: “Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, so vata bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu saṃvutakārī.
mn105:29.8.eng: “In the same way, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.

mn105:29.9.pli: ‘Upadhi dukkhassa mūlan’ti—iti viditvā nirupadhi upadhisaṅkhaye vimutto upadhismiṃ vā kāyaṃ upasaṃharissati cittaṃ vā uppādessatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mn105:29.9.eng: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.

mn105:30.1.eng: Suppose there was a lethal viper.

mn105:30.2.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhapaṭikūlo.
mn105:30.2.eng: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.

mn105:30.4.pli: api nu so puriso amussa āsīvisassa ghoravisassa hatthaṃ vā aṅguṭṭhaṃ vā dajjā yaṃ jaññā:
mn105:30.4.eng: Would that person give that lethal viper their hand or finger if they knew that

mn105:30.5.pli: ‘imināhaṃ daṭṭho maraṇaṃ vā nigacchāmi maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhan’”ti?
mn105:30.5.eng: it would result in death or deadly suffering?”

mn105:30.7.pli: “Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, so vata bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu saṃvutakārī.
mn105:30.7.eng: “In the same way, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.

mn105:30.8.pli: ‘Upadhi dukkhassa mūlan’ti—iti viditvā nirupadhi upadhisaṅkhaye vimutto upadhismiṃ vā kāyaṃ upasaṃharissati cittaṃ vā uppādessatīti—
mn105:30.8.eng: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.”

mn105:30.10.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn105:30.11.pli: Attamano sunakkhatto licchaviputto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn105:30.11.eng: Satisfied, Sunakkhatta of the Licchavi clan approved what the Buddha said.
